content.detail: For an Intro to User-Centered Design course, this assignment gave me the opportunity to choose an activity that I could design an integrated app experience for. Based on my familiarity with the L.A. Zoo and its current app, I pursued the design of an app that could provide more educational and entertaining interactions with the park.

content.title: Proposal: Description of the App
content.detail:
The L.A. Zoo already has an app that allows users to unlock fun facts about 14 animals and exhibits through GPS-enabling. While this encourages visitors to go to the zoo, it is limited in both the variety of information it provides (the zoo contains 250+ species and more activities) and in its capability for users to recall memories through the app.

This new app will improve the experience by providing a larger list of activities and their details to bring better awareness and preparation to guests as well as a space to save their favorite animals/locations and document through notes and media—thereby creating personal album memories from the zoo to download, already organized through the app.

content.title: Affordances
content.detail: Due to this app being a newly integrated addition to the Zoo's experience, several affordances should be considered to include in the park and encourage more use with the app.

content.subtitle: Physical Affordances
content.detail:
• QR Codes: Signs at Exhibits will indicate that you can learn more through a provided QR Code to scan through the app
  • RFID: These will sense nearby locations if you may want to learn more about a nearby show, food vendor, or shop

content.subtitle: Virtual Affordances
content.detail:
• Lock/Unlock Icons: Indicates which animals and exhibits are accessible based on your location
  • In-app "Favorite" Button: Indicates that you may want to save the animal/location for later reference

content.title: Opportunities
content.detail:
The potential problem of how to download the information especially if there are multiple visits had then adjusted the vision for the application to optionally save each new zoo visit experience into a new album rather than continuously add more and more notes/media to the same show or animal exhibit.

Understanding what the zoo experience and current app experience lacked in—content and engagement—allowed me to consider more ways to allow affordances by having QR codes for every exhibit and to better consider the needs of those who not only want to learn from the experience but also remember what they learned—through a documentation outlet.

To promote more continuous engagement in the app, the following features could be developed in later versions of the app:

  • Heat map of the zoo to indicate which exhibits have more active animals to learn from during different parts of the day, allowing more efficient/thorough guest experiences
  • Zoo and its Store and Food Vendors: hours, menus/offerings, and discounts/specialties
  • Interactive map that records/tracks location throughout the day and timestamps/geotags your notes/media
